climbs.name: Using Your Nose
climbs.fa: Chris Miller, Jacob Colella and Lisa Guindon, March 2000

content.description:
Climbs a left-arching crack to where it ends and then joins the upper face of

Cherry Blossom

to the summit. Gear belay and down-climb to climber's right.
content.location:
Just right of

Don't Touch That Flake

.

content.description: Start 20 feet around and right from Using Your Nose (toward Mary Worth Buttress) at an obvious crack. Climb the crack to the top.
content.location: Start 20 feet around and right from Using Your Nose (toward Mary Worth Buttress) at an obvious crack.

climbs.name: Don't Touch That Flake
climbs.fa: Mike Tower, Warren Hughes, Mike Van Volkem, Dean Tower, February 1988

content.description:
This gem lies on the west face of Sphinx Rock, directly off the trail, and just right of Cherry Blossom, another marvelous route.

Climb the slabby face on the right taking care to not touch or weight the prominent flake system. Belay on top and walk off.

A better name would be

Don't Touch This Route

- what a  waste of bolts. Minus one star out of five.

climbs.name: Cleopatra
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Yvonne MacPherson, Todd Gordon, & Alan Bartlett, October 1989

content.description: The route starts on the north-facing side of a large squarish block on the left side of the Sphinx formation. Scramble up boulders to access the base. An easy layback/flake leads to continuous steep smears past six bolts to the summit. The excellent rock and moves make this a classic Josh friction route.
content.protection: 6 bolts provide excellent protection. 2 bolt anchor on top; rap off 70 feet to ground.

climbs.name: Cherry Blossom
climbs.fa: Mike Van Volkem, Nadine Widding, Flo Van Volkem, February 1988

content.description: A good warm up route, with good pro for the hard moves. Definitely not as straight forward as some routes (in a good way). You have to run out the upper easy slab. Descend down and right.
content.protection: Three bolts protect fun and unusual face moves for the first 25 feet; run it out after that. Bring 2-3 inch pro for the belay (top of Afterthought crack).

climbs.name: Afterthought
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller, December 1995   (Lead) Bob Gaines, Scott Cosgrove, November 1996

content.description: This fun route involves various stemming and palming maneuvers which make the bottom section of this route seem longer than it is.  Well worth doing if your passing by. Walk off the south side slabs.
content.protection: 3 bolts protect the hard moves; above easy groove/crack; gear needed for belay/anchor (2-3 inches).
